November 9, 2022

Avoiding the shiny object syndrome

Founder Project-management 3 minutes to read

I have always said, ‚ÄúIdeas are easy. Execution is what matters,‚Äù countless times. When I was working as a product manager, I was good at ruthlessly prioritizing the minimum valuable product in spite of ambiguity. One of my big product practice crusades has been around scope creep. You can‚Äôt front load everything and chase every idea all at once. Because if everything is important, then nothing is important.

So why is it so hard right now? Never mind scope creep on one idea. I keep branching into multiple product ideas that are so disparate that I‚Äôve found myself on WebMD and Psychology Today to check if I have adult-onset ADHD. I‚Äôm convinced I at least have a mild case of ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt get into a flow and do one thing for a long time because I threw discipline out the window after high school.‚Äù It doesn‚Äôt roll off the tongue like ADHD.

My theory on why I can‚Äôt follow through at the moment is as follows. Working as a product person at a company, I work with the company vision. No matter how ambiguous the product vision and roadmap might be, I have an inkling of where I need to get to eventually. Without this focus, I‚Äôm turning my attention towards every problem that I am passionate about.

Heuristics for attention prioritization

To help focus, I spent some time thinking about how to prioritize my attention today. And I‚Äôve decided to borrow some of my heuristics from the kitchen.

  • Front-burner: This is the main meal I‚Äôm cooking right now. It‚Äôs the primary project that is receiving my attention because it‚Äôs on power boil.
  • Back-burner: This is the side dish I‚Äôve got on simmer. It‚Äôs a secondary project that may get my attention once in awhile because I gotta stir it occasionally.
  • Pantry: This stores anything and everything from pots and pans to my unopened tub of gochujang and my extra jar of cornichon. It‚Äôs miscellaneous references, fleeting ideas, inspirational podcasts, and any other random thoughts that may be used in my meal‚Äîor used to cook a whole new meal down the line.
  • Compost: This is the disposal. In goes whatever that spoiled in the pantry or if I burnt the food. It‚Äôs abandoned ideas that I will choose not to pursue.

With this mental model in mind, I was able to comb through a list of 70-something ideas that I had jotted down. Most have now been shelved in the pantry or chucked away into the compost bin. I‚Äôve decided to add on side dish to the back-burner, though. I‚Äôve always been passionate about all things analog; so I want to try making stationery. Yes, it‚Äôs a saturated market. Yes, it‚Äôll likely lead to nowhere. So why am I toiling with this?

First, I want to use my time doing something I enjoy. Both as a product creator and as a user. I feel grateful that I‚Äôm currently in a weird limbo where I don‚Äôt feel compelled to be productive and to produce outputs all the damn time. So I‚Äôll capitalize on this moment. I‚Äôll eventually have to figure out how to bring in income to live my life. But for now, I‚Äôll happily work on my entrepreneurial discipline and routine by building something I enjoy.

Second, I‚Äôve only ever managed digital product. The extra side dish I‚Äôm whipping up is a physical product. It‚Äôll be interesting to explore how product validations compare and contrast between physical and digital product management. And the shininess of the new challenge also intrigues me, too.

If you found my blog helpful, please consider adding to my book fund. You can also make requests on what I should read next!
